name: 3-(6-hydroxy-1,2,3,4-tetrahydronaphthalen-2-yl)-2,2-dimethylpentanoic acid
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2140

name: 3-(6-hydroxy-1,2,3,4-tetrahydronaphthalen-2-yl)-2,2-dimethylpentanoic acid
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2140
Reason:
Starting with base unit naphthalene which has a melting point of 80.1 degrees Celsius, we now consider the effects of various functional groups on the melting point: 
- The presence of the hydroxyl group typically raises the melting point due to the capacity for hydrogen bonding; an increment of around +40 degrees Celsius may be appropriate for such functionality. 
- The 1,2,3,4-tetrahydronaphthalene structure reduces the melting point relative to naphthalene, due to the reduced aromaticity and reduced planarity which usually provide stability; a decrement of about -20 degrees Celsius may be relevant for this change in structure. 
- The carboxylic acid group generally increases the melting point due to hydrogen bonding and the potential for dimer formation; an increment of around +50 degrees Celsius could be applied for this functionality. 
- The presence of two methyl groups attached to the same carbon atom (geminal dimethyl) usually increases the melting point due to increased molecular symmetry and reduced conformational entropy; this could contribute an increment of about +5 degrees Celsius. 
The sum of these group effects is used to predict the melting point of the target compound.
